Dr. Carole Lieberman is listed in numerous ''Who's Who'' directories{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}, including ''The World Who's Who of American Women'' and International Who's Who in Medicine. She is a member of the [[Writers Guild of America]], [[Screen Actors Guild|SAG]], [[AFTRA]] and the [[Academy of Television Arts and Sciences]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
Dr. Carole Lieberman is listed in numerous ''Who's Who'' directories{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}, including ''The World Who's Who of American Women'' and International Who's Who in Medicine. She is a member of the [[Writers Guild of America]], [[Screen Actors Guild|SAG]], [[AFTRA]] and the [[Academy of Television Arts and Sciences]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
  +   +
==Video games incident==
  +
In February 2011, Dr. Lieberman gathered attention for her claim linking rising trends between rape and videogames during an interview with [[FOX News]]: '''"The increase in rapes can be attributed in large part to the playing out of [sexual] scenes in video games"'''.<ref>http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2011/02/08/bulletstorm-worst-game-kids/</ref>
  +
Despite the seriousness of Liebermanâs allegations, when asked by Wired.com multiple times to clarify her comments, she failed to cite a single study, statistic, or piece of evidence that proved her point. Dr. Lieberman has responded with a single study to support her case as of February 14, 2011: "Violent Video Game Effects on Aggression, Empathy, and Prosocial
  +
Behavior in Eastern and Western Countries: A Meta-Analytic Review". <ref>http://www.psychology.iastate.edu/faculty/caa/abstracts/2010-2014/10ASISBSRS.pdf</ref> Interestingly, no mention of sexual crime is mentioned in the article, let alone a scientific correlation between the two, making Dr. Lieberman's claims seem like a ploy for attention rather than a call to address an important societal issue.
  +   +
Dr. Lieberman is now attempting to rectify her relationship with gamers by offering a more detailed explanation of her thoughts to anyone who would take the time to email her. This change of heart was in response to plummeting ratings of her book, "Bad Girls", on Amazon.com. <ref>http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2011/02/10/gamers-assault-bulletstorm-criticizing-psychologist-on-amazon.aspx</ref><ref>http://www.amazon.com/Bad-Girls-Carole-Lieberman/product-reviews/292386512X/ref=cm_cr_pr_hist_1?ie=UTF8&showViewpoints=0&filterBy=addOneStar</ref><ref>http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2011/02/15/bulletstormgate-lieberman-offers-evidence/</ref> Nevertheless, she is staying by her position. <ref>http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/107764-Games-Cause-Rape-Psychiatrist-Defends-Her-Position</ref>
  +   +
